Message.Content: [Bloomberg created note: Remains logged in.]
[Bloomberg created note: Remains logged in.]

Steady selling with weak bidding but the rate of change of the descent is clearly losing steam. Looks like we'll test the up support line formed from 1/27 low connected to the 3/30 low. Should hold or suffer only a token break. Playing with 100 DMA now, flipping stops out on either side out of boredom. This is not a panicked chart.

DXY in two parallelograms
First, we revisit the old down parallelogram on the US dollar which correctly targeted the bottom months before it happened. Like many apex targets it became a relevant level, and remains so to this day, as we are trading so close to it now.
But as we did go to a new reaction low and have subsequently rallied, we now have a new long term down parallelogram. Current price action has thus far been contained by the 2/3rds internal line off the low. The new parallelogram allows for, but does not require, three more months of countertrend rally. However, it points into the low 80s late summer next year. Let's face it. Rolling over the US dollar is no easy thing to do. It’s monumental. Titanic. Very large long term forces are at play here and thus will take time. So far though, all we have on our hands is a neutral sideways range after a low.
TIPs/Real yields today have rallied! 10yr tips up roughly 20/32nds = 2.6bps whilst 10yr breakevens 4bps WIDER. Now that's a change! Trader positioning day before CPI tomorrow is our best guess.
Bouncing between the 100DMA and the 50DMA
Hanging out below a dead flat 50DMA. Includes cosmetics and personal care, pharmaceuticals, soft drinks, tobacco, and food products.
At the top of the sideways range it formed after breaking up trend line. At a sideways 50DMA

"Ho Chi Minh City issued a 15-day stay-home order beginning July 9 that limited residents’ movements to going to work deemed essential and seeking food, medicines, or urgent medical assistance. The health ministry on Saturday forecast the city may see 10,000 more local infections in coming days, according to the government website." (BN)
Vietnam equities are down -3.77% following new lockdown orders
With today's close the S&P 500 posted a record high for the 10th time in the last 12 trading days
Not exactly blasting though the 100DMA as the Transports close fractionally below. DMI still show a lot more sell pressure than buy pressure.
Avis treading water below the 100DMA as the MACD continues to plummet. More pain ahead.
GS led the Dow Industrials higher today ahead of the imminent release of its earnings call. Nice move above the 20 DMA and 50 DMA with MACD turning up.

"investors much less bullish on growth, profits & yield curve steepening, have unwound junk>quality, small>large, value>growth trades back to Oct’20 levels, but maintain big longs in stocks (back to tech) & commodities"
- Long tech back as most crowded trade - Inflation seen as biggest tail risk - 70% say inflation transitory, 22% see higher inflation in nxt 12mths - 73% say econ. is mid- or late-cycle (was 9% in June!!) - 40% think 1st Fed hike comes Jan 23
BofA Fund Manager Survey

China June trade data revealed an unexpected rise in export growth while import growth also topped estimates. Data had been expected to show impacts from Guangdong coronavirus outbreak affecting port activity in Shenzhen. China customs export growth accelerated to 32.2% y/y in June from 27.9% in the prior month. Imports were up 36.7% vs consensus 30.0%.

Germany June CPI which came in line with estimates. France June CPI came in line as well, +1.5% y/y vs preliminary +1.5%, while Switzerland June PPI was a touch below estimates, coming at +2.9% y/y vs consensus +3.2% and prior +3.2%.

EU will come to the market today for a dual-tranche transaction with funds for three of its programmes set to be raised: NGEU, EFSM and MFA.
* This is the first time that the EU has held a substantial syndication combining more than one of its programmes. * E5.25bln is due to be sold of an EFSM/MFA 10-year bond. The E5bln of EFSM funds had already been scheduled for July in the latest investor updates and form a rollover of the 2.75% Sep-21 bond. While E1.8bln of MFA funding is planned for H2. * E10bln will be sold of a new NGEU 20-year bond. This will be the third NGEU transaction following the initial launch of the E20bln 10-year bond on 15 June and the dual-tranche 5/30-year E9bln/E6bln on 29 June.

Given the huge book sizes seen for all EU transactions, we expect a very successful transaction again today. * Timing: For the two June NGEU transactions, books opened just before 8:00BST with spreads set by 9:00BST. Pricing has then been between 14:15-14:30BST.

***EU € 10+20YR DUAL TRANCHE - Update / Final Terms***
Issuer: European Union (EU) Ratings: AAA (st) / AAA (st) / Aaa (st) / AAA (st) / AA (pos) - DBRS / Fitch / Moody’s / Scope / S&P Risk Weighting: 0% Format & Type: RegS (Category 1) Bearer (TEFRA Rules apply, no communications with or into the US or Canada (excluding Ontario)), NGN Settlement: 20-Jul-2021 (T+5) Coupon: Fixed, Ann, ACT/ACT ICMA, short first ************************************************************ Maturity: 22-Apr-2031 | 04-Jul-2041 Tranche Size: EUR 5.25bn no-grow | EUR 10bn no-grow Final Spread: MS -6bp | MS +7bp ISIN: EU000A3KT6A3 | EU000A3KT6B1 UoP: 5bn EFSM / 250mm MFA | NGEU Book Update: >€47bn (ex JLM) | >€81bn (ex JLM) ************************************************************

We look to enter a new long on the L-U1L-Z2 spread targeting a move to 0.48. We look to buy at 0.345 50% risk. Current market is 0.34/0.345 3500/500. Pattern will be negated on a close below 0.285 which would also see a break of the 6-month trendline support. Our take profit target level is at 0.48 but expect to see good resistance at the previous high at 0.42. Brogden

In FX, the ZAR is the main exception, suffering from covid issues and local violence, as well as perhaps correcting a past overshoot (as we have seen with commodity currencies previously)
I think we are increasingly in an event driven macro environment, as the big covid trends give way to more ideosyncratic vol. On the covid front, we are focussed on whether the delta spikes are also moving into hospitalizations. UK has been a pretty positive story on that front, and it is hard to fund countries where the hospitalization trends look problematic.
But this is what we are watching. On the news front, I think it is worth highlighting just how strong the momentum in the trade data was
I like to simply look at the SA momentum in the ex oil data
it is very robust. Not all Chinese data are weak. Wow, on the core reading... Jens Nordvig

The index for used cars and trucks continued to rise sharply, increasing 10.5 percent in June. This increase accounted for more than one-third of the seasonally adjusted all items increase. The food index increased 0.8 percent in June, a larger increase than the 0.4-percent increase reported for May. The energy index increased 1.5 percent in June, with the gasoline index rising 2.5 percent over the month. Bonds hardly care, although short end moving a bit (3y up 2.9bp). Bonds back to lower yields... - Nordvig

"The June CPI report shows reopening-sensitive categories dominating price pressures for a third straight month. We estimate 55% of the month-over-month increase came from six components -- used cars, rental cars, vehicle insurance, lodging, airfares, and food away from home -- up from 52% the prior month. Including energy prices, that proportion rises to 66% = transitory" Not sure what dealer sent this Larry, PM in NYC

" cpi is bogus but taken at face value this is likely the high print (rent cpi makes that call a lil tougher). But that's why I think bonds taking it in stride. Again cpi is bogus measurement anyway" PM in NYC

Hot CPI, comes in +0.9% vs 0.5% exp. Core CPI also above est. RECAP
- Culprits once again used vehicle prices, which rose another 10% m/m
- Gasoline +2.5% m/m after down prior months, mostly due to the upward drift in WTI in June
- Food inflation also on the high side, with +0.8% m/m (meat and soda price hikes), as were overall commodities.
- On the plus side, OER (housing) remained relatively subdued. Also real average weekly earnings down again (3rd month in a row).
- Reaction: Rates are relatively benign on surprise CPI strength. Front end rates are rallying while back end says anchored for now. Breakevens move also very muted.
*PEPSICO CFO JOHNSTON SEES COST PRESSURE LATER THIS YEAR *PEPSICO CFO SAYS FURTHER INFLATION COULD PROMPT PRICE INCREASES

Interesting; Of the 329 line items in the monthly CPI report, 236, or 72% of total, recorded a m/m increase of less than 1%. Only 17 items (5%) of line items recorded an increase of more than 3% m/m.
Almost all these 17 items were related to 3 things; cars, pork and oil.

" Disinflationary pressures will return in a strong way as companies rework their structures, More broadly, continued inflation pressures will speed tech integration, global employee diversification, outsourcing, and employee reductions. One thing we know as certain is CEO's protect their own comp first and most is related to stock prices. They will attempt to pass through expenses to end buyers but still highly competitive. The biggest thing they can control is expenses thus margin expansion a priority. I maintain the middle manager, mostly Boomers buying their time until retirement, is the most endangered employee right now as companies look to remove fat." cio Philly
"Not bogus. Every measurement has its issues and saying CPI is bogus because of rent equiv is wrong. You just have to strip out things you think are outliers" CIO Philly

" I am no economist, but if the mkt was really worried about inflation, then FI would be trading differently. I am no economist, but if the mkt was really worried about inflation, then FI would be trading differently."

(Bloomberg) -- A NIH-supported research team found that people who received both doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech mRNA vaccine, held hallmarks of a strong, persistent immune response against SARS-CoV-2 that could be protective for years to come. • The findings add evidence that people who received mRNA Covid-19 vaccines may not need an additional “booster” shot for quite some time, unless SARS-CoV-2 evolves into new forms, or variants, that can evade this vaccine-induced immunity • By the 15- week mark, all of the participants sampled continued to have active germinal centers in their lymph nodes

Sternlicht’s Starwood Gives Up on Malls After Plunge in Values
Starwood Capital Group owned 30 malls before the Covid-19 pandemic. It’s now down to eight. As values for retail properties plunge, Barry Sternlicht’s investment firm has been selling shopping centers across the U.S. at money-losing prices. Its remaining malls are being managed by outside companies that potentially will seek new owners.
U.S. STATE DEPARTMENT SAYS BUSINESSES AND INDIVIDUALS WHO DO NOT EXIT XINJIANG-CONNECTED SUPPLY CHAINS 'COULD RUN A HIGH RISK OF VIOLATING U.S. LAW'

Assuming the FED begins by end of 2022 or beginning 023.. How far and how fast will they go... 110 bp's in 3 years. ..and a Terminal rate of around 1.50%.....

GS - New all time highs for AAPL AMZN MSFT GOOGL Our mega cap tech basket is +10% in a month - now +27% on the year. This remains a pain trade - specifically amongst mutual funds given their low positioning in FAAMG.

JPMorgan missed on FICC sales & trading while beating on equities and investment banking. The quarter included $3 billion in credit reserve releases firmwide, which was bigger than expected. Managed NII missed. Revenues at the six largest U.S. lenders are projected to fall about 5%, dragged down by a drop in trading and loans. Still, a surge in dealmaking fees and cash reserves may soften the blow.

Dividend divide. The BOE fully removed dividend restrictions, leaving the industry to resume payouts as they wish. But the ECB may take steps to stop excess payments. The central bank will probably lift a cap later this year but push lenders to use a moderate dividend policy, official Margarita Delgado said. Banks that splurge may face higher capital requirements or qualitative measures.
{EUFN US EQUITY}

Crude faces the threat of significant tightening and higher prices unless OPEC+ resolves its standoff and boosts production, the IEA warned. Consumption will jump by 5.4 million barrels a day this year. Still, there's a remote possibility of a price war, the agency said. More evidence of falling supply: U.S. oil stockpiles probably fell for an eighth week, the longest run of declines in more than three years. - BN
Earlier this year most people were forecasting ~2% inflation for the entire year. So far we already have +3.6% inflation (or 7.3%) at an annual rate.
"Not excited about other financials if this is reaction to JPM and GS"

New highs minus New lows on the NYSE should be at least 300 a day if not 500 to be deemed healthy. Anything sub 100 is simply pathetic. On May 10th new highs less New lows hit 506. A couple of days ago it was less than zero. That. Is. Bad. The shorter term moving averages are below the longer terms moving averages while cash indices are at new price highs. This type of action usually precedes a price correction though the negative divergence can last a few more weeks. It's simple: we're on borrowed time!
The number of 52 week highs on the NYSE is also fading. We have extremely weak breadth for a market that is hitting new all-time highs...

XLG, which is an etf of the 50 largest capitalization stocks in the S&P, is carrying the entire index. So if you want to know what is happening to the larger index, this etf is key. What is it telling us? 1) run away bull run. 2) hyper-extended which means there is no support until the old high. This means the entire rally is easily retraceable. Why? Well imagine if it went up in a sequence of steps with periods of consolidation. Then it would have a series of support levels to halt a decline. 3) overbought. The last time it got this overbought a) it kept on rallying and b) that rally was subsequently more than 100% retraced. It is bad when 10% of the stocks are doing more than 100% of the work. It is even worse when they are hyper-extended and overbought!
Spanish stocks delivered a sell signal by going above and then below the 100 DMA

Color from Derivative Desk
Options market is the tail wagging the dog. We are hearing gamma exposure is at one of its highest levels of the year heading into OpEx (monthly options expiration this Friday). This tends to:
1. Keep the S&P 500 relatively stable, with mean-reverting intraday moves 2. Volatility tends to be sold into Friday, with large moves more likely in the week following OpEx.
This speaks to the lack of movement in the S&P today. Unusual to have that high of an inflation print and for SPX to be dead flat.

Keep in mind, this was very similar to February 2020. Covid was becoming obvious but volatility continued to be sold into February's Opex. The Friday OpEx in Feb was the day the market finally began to unravel...
New cases per day are looking much higher in regions with less vaccinations. Keep in mind, which vaccine is taken matters a whole lot here
The fate of the USD is tied to breakevens

Does the poor Treasury auction confirm the recent floor in rates?
TLT now down 75 basis points, suddenly CPI matters a lot more....

Post-Auction: "Oh wait, nobody wants 30 year Treasuries at -3.4% yield..."

Fed’s Barkin Says Higher Wages Are Adding to Inflation Pressures
Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond President Thomas Barkin said higher wages of lower-income workers in the U.S. are contributing to inflationary pressures, adding the outlook for more lasting changes should be clearer by September.
“We see wages for lower-skilled workers rising as workforce participation stays stubbornly low,” Barkin said in an essay on the bank’s Website. “We also see price increases”.
Wage growth was one of the major engines we highlighted in our Zurich conference presentation, see our slides here....

STRUCTURED PIPELINE: Summer of Deals Kicking Into High Gear
U.S. ABS issuers are poised for a busy week after a sluggish start to July. Auto deals this week will be a mix of prime, subprime, floorplan and lease, including a subprime mega transaction from Santander Consumer that can grow to as much as $2.5 billion. At approximately $151.1 billion, YTD ABS sales are already 65.5% higher than this time in 2020.
{NSN QW74D0T0G1KW<GO>}: 'Oil Supply Just Can’t Keep Up With Summer Driving Season'

Supplies of crude, as measured by inventories, and oil in transit have fallen by more than three million barrels a day in June from the prior month of May, said Ed Morse, Citigroup global head of commodities research. “And spreads -- the best indicators of market strength -- reflect an “extremely tight market,” he said.
At the same time, OPEC and its allies have been squabbling over returning supply to the market that they shuttered during the pandemic. The 23-member nation coalition has been unable to agree on a production hike for August, and today, the International Energy Agency warned that the standoff may inflict “a deepening supply deficit.” - Bloomberg

Ytd fedl receipts 3.05t .. Ytd federal expenses excluding income support and defense 3.36t .. Safe to say we are in perma deficit mode.. The notion the fed can taper for any length of time or in any meaningful way has to be challenged

Great chart here from Nordea: Rising inflation (food prices) speaks to heightened political uncertainty. The underlying trigger for riots/protests in South Africa and Cuba is likely the development in food prices.
Silver has formed a massive cup and handle on a 50 year chart. If the market finally begins to price longer-term inflation, we expect a large breakout here.

Pretty amazing we got the highest inflation print in 30 years today and silver is red....
{XAG CURRENCY}

Attachment.FileName: inflation in us vs europe and japan.JPG

Message.Content: US CPI completely diverging from the rest of the world. Keep in mind, Europe in Japan are well behind the US in terms of economic restrictions...

One dynamic we highlighted in our recent conference presentation is the vast majority of the world still has significant Covid restrictions. These restrictions are correlated with higher savings rates Meanwhile, the U.S. Savings rate has come down significantly in recent months. As a proxy for the rest of the developed world opening up, this speaks to cash globally coming back into the economy over the next 12 months.
Meanwhile, even with restrictions still in place, almost the entire world is already seeing relatively high inflation on a YoY basis....

Color from a Lumber producer
the most important factors impacting lumber prices:
- Housing Demand - Lumber production levels vs demand - Mill inventories and Distribution Inventories - Disruption concerns in log supply as well as transportation ( rail. Trucking ) - Mill economics ( Manufacturing costs and Log prices ) could change operating levels - Gov’t Policy ( Annual allowable cut reductions, Tenure take-back, Stumpage ) - Weather risks like Wildfire

"The biggest driver has been a “supply chain “ disruption. Supply could not keep up with DIY demand and then the builders/contractors were shorted. Today, DIY is off 30% making supply available to the distribution networks. But buyers have stayed on the sidelines long enough to see prices around $650. The floor is near and I think lumber supply will be well subscribed as buyers step in. Market demand continues to be fairly strong."
